newsitem.title: USA: NYC Mayor proposes $400 mln FY '99 rainy day fund.
newsitem.headline: NYC Mayor proposes $400 mln FY '99 rainy day fund.

text.p: New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani on Thursday proposed an unofficial rainy day fund -- a term used to describe short-term stabilization funds -- using an expected $200 million surplus plus the General Reserve.
"This is the way we can create a Rainy Day Fund within the existing law," Giuliani told reporters at a City Hall news conference at which he unveiled his $33.5 billion fiscal 1998 budget.
The Democrat-led City Council has proposed creating a rainy day fund, but such a measure would require Albany's approval.
The Giuliani Administration plans to use the $200 million surplus with which it expects to end fiscal 1998 by prepaying debt service in fiscal 1999. The city starts its new fiscal years on July 1.
Adding the projected surplus to the $200 million cash balance in the General Reserve produces the $400 million total the mayor proposed.

But New York City officials, who declined to be named, noted that the city, which is required to balance its books at year-end, typically leaves $40 million of the General Fund balance in the previous year to cover any unexpected contingencies.
As a resut, the amount available for an unofficial rainy day fund would fall to $360 million, though the city sources said that still was a fairly comfortable cash cushion.
